title: The Kernel Beta Process

author: David E. Carlson, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Duke University

segmentation: So in the paper we introduce a new levy process which we call the kernel beta process, and this is a generalization of the beta process.
So what happens is often we have some type of covariates, such as in an image.
We have spatial covariance, but in the beta process we don't take into account any of the spatial information.
And we would like to be able to do this.
So we introduce on each of the atoms a covariate.
So basically a spatial location as well as kernel parameters, and then we use this kernel to determine which parts of the kernel beta process are most appropriate to use for the data.

Additionally, we have a fair amount of theory in the paper, so we showed that we are able to derive the characteristic function of the kernel beta process and we show that it is in fact a valid baby process.
We also do many of the theoretical properties of the kernel beta process.

We derive the expectation of the kernel beta process at a covariate acts, and we find that the apriori expectation is just the product of the prior for the beta process times the expectation of the kernel.

Additionally, we'd like to be able to evaluate what happens at when we draw data covariate X, as well as a covariate X, and we find that apriori the correlation between these two covariates is just going to depend on the covariates themselves and the kernel parameters.
And finally, we've shown several experiments in the paper.
And we managed to get state of the art results.
So at the top of the slide we're showing results from music analysis.
So what we're showing is the correlation matrix through time of the song A day in the life by The Beatles.
So the kernel beta processes on the left side, and it shows that we're able to determine the repeated structure.
But allowing the process to smoothly very, and we compare this to a beta process factor analysis model, as well as independent hierarchal dearsley process hidden Markov model.
And we find that we get improved results by using the kernel beta process over these other models.

We've also done results on image processing, so we add spiky noise into an image and then we try to recover the original image, and we've compared the kernel beta process factor analysis model with two variants of the beta process factor analysis model and we find that we get improved PSNR as well as improved visual results.
If anybody has any questions about any of the theory or any of their relative results, please come see me wear poster 95.
Thank you.
